For every integer `n`, the remainder of `n` when divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. (Or equivalently, every integer `n` is congruent to 0 or 1 modulo 2.)

name: Int.emod_two_eq_zero_or_one
docString: For every integer `n`, the remainder of `n` when divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. (Or equivalently, every integer `n` is congruent to 0 or 1 modulo 2.)

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, if the remainder when `n` is divided by 4 equals 1 then the remainder when `n` is divided by 2 also equals 1. In other words, if a natural number is one more than a multiple of 4, then it is an odd number.

name: Nat.odd_of_mod_four_eq_one
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, if the remainder when `n` is divided by 4 equals 1 then the remainder when `n` is divided by 2 also equals 1. In other words, if a natural number is one more than a multiple of 4, then it is an odd number.

For every integer `n`, `n` divides `n`. In other words, `n` | `n` for all integers `n`.

type: ∀ (n : ℤ), n ∣ n
name: Int.dvd_refl
docString: For every integer `n`, `n` divides `n`. In other words, `n` | `n` for all integers `n`.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, if the modulus of `n` divided by 4 equals 3, then the modulus of `n` divided by 2 equals 1. In mathematical terms, it asserts that if `n` modulo 4 is 3, then `n` is necessarily odd (since `n` modulo 2 is 1).

name: Nat.odd_of_mod_four_eq_three
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, if the modulus of `n` divided by 4 equals 3, then the modulus of `n` divided by 2 equals 1. In mathematical terms, it asserts that if `n` modulo 4 is 3, then `n` is necessarily odd (since `n` modulo 2 is 1).

If for all `n ≠ 0 ∈ ℤ`, `n • A = A`, then `A` is divisible.

type: (A : Type u_1) → [inst : AddCommGroup A] → (∀ {n : ℤ}, n ≠ 0 → n • ⊤ = ⊤) → DivisibleBy A ℤ
name: AddCommGroup.divisibleByIntOfSMulTopEqTop
docString: If for all `n ≠ 0 ∈ ℤ`, `n • A = A`, then `A` is divisible.

Multiplication modulo `n`

type: {n : ℕ} → Fin n → Fin n → Fin n
name: Fin.mul
docString: Multiplication modulo `n`

If `n` is a squarefree natural number, then `-1` is a square modulo `n` if and only if
`n` has no divisor `q` that is `≡ 3 mod 4`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Squarefree n → (IsSquare (-1) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, q ∣ n → q % 4 ≠ 3)
name: ZMod.isSquare_neg_one_iff'
docString:
If `n` is a squarefree natural number, then `-1` is a square modulo `n` if and only if
`n` has no divisor `q` that is `≡ 3 mod 4`.

Subtraction modulo `n`

type: {n : ℕ} → Fin n → Fin n → Fin n

docString: Subtraction modulo `n`

If `n` is a squarefree natural number, then `-1` is a square modulo `n` if and only if
`n` is not divisible by a prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Squarefree n → (IsSquare (-1) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime q → q ∣ n → q % 4 ≠ 3)
name: ZMod.isSquare_neg_one_iff
docString:
If `n` is a squarefree natural number, then `-1` is a square modulo `n` if and only if
`n` is not divisible by a prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3`.

The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

type: ℕ → Type
name: ZMod
docString: The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

If a prime `p` divides `n` such that `-1` is a square modulo `n`, then `p % 4 ≠ 3`.

type: ∀ {p n : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → p ∣ n → IsSquare (-1) → p % 4 ≠ 3
name: Nat.Prime.mod_four_ne_three_of_dvd_isSquare_neg_one
docString: If a prime `p` divides `n` such that `-1` is a square modulo `n`, then `p % 4 ≠ 3`.

A polynomial over the integers is divisible by `n : ℕ`
if and only if it is zero over `ZMod n`.

type:
∀ {σ : Type u_1} (n : ℕ) (φ : MvPolynomial σ ℤ),
  MvPolynomial.C ↑n ∣ φ ↔ (MvPolynomial.map (Int.castRingHom (ZMod n))) φ = 0
name: MvPolynomial.C_dvd_iff_zmod
docString:
A polynomial over the integers is divisible by `n : ℕ`
if and only if it is zero over `ZMod n`.

If `n > 0` then `m` is not divisible by `n` iff it is between `n * k` and `n * (k + 1)`
for some `k`.

name: Int.exists_lt_and_lt_iff_not_dvd
docString:
If `n > 0` then `m` is not divisible by `n` iff it is between `n * k` and `n * (k + 1)`
for some `k`.

If the integer `n` is a sum of two squares of coprime integers,
